bibl.title: Letter from Mabel Houston Lazear to James Carroll, November 10, [1900]

div1.p: Mabel H. Lazear asks Carroll for information on the circumstances of Jesse Lazear's death.

div1.head: Letter from Mabel Houston Lazear to James Carroll, November 10, [1900]
div1.p:
Your
kind letter and
receipted bills re-
ceived - for which
I wish to thank you
very much -

I am so very anx-
SD
B
ious to know more
about these circumstances
as to how Dr Lazear
contrasted yellow fever

In a note from Gener-
al Wood yesterday he
writes that Dr Lazear
allowed a mosquito
to bit him that had
just bitten a yellow
fever patience.

Is it possible Gen.
Wood could be mis-
take - much as I know
Dr Lazear loved his
work I can hardly
think he could have
allowed his enthus-
ias to carry him so
far.

He had talked much
to me about his
work knowing that I
took the greatest in-
terest in it-

I knew nothing about
your having the favor
or that it had again
broken out - so that
the shock was more
terrible than thing
we could imagine-
I suppose Dr Lazears idea
in not telling me was
to keep me from wor-
rying - He was always
so thoughtful where
my comfort was con-
serve that I can-
not believe he could
have done anything
so dangerous. --

It will be the great-
est favor if you
will be so kind
is to write to me
and give me more
particulars-

Did he feel positive
he would get well if
he took the fever
and did he know
that he could not
get well as soon as
you did? --

I wonder that I can
ask such a favor
of a stranger but
the people with whom
Dr Lazear worked
seem very near-
He had often spoken
of you -

Please thank Mrs
Carroll for her kind
message -

Hope I may know you
both some time.

I feel I have not
made myself very
clear but it is al-
most impossible to
write -

Again thanking you
for the money order
